repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Secondary Education Quality
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Thailand Secondary Education Quality
            Improvement Projectre had a satisfactory outcome, highly
            likely sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, overall unsatisfactory Bank performance, and overall
            unsatisfactory. Key lessons learned from the project
            concerned bank supervision, project design and management,
            staff development, and instructional reform.  They are as
            follows: 1. Project implementation can be negatively
            affected if Bank supervision is not maintained in a timely
            and consistent manner. 2. Effective Bank supervision
            requires coupling experienced task managers with adequate
            staffing on the ground. 3. To quickly identify and address
            supervision problems before they affect project
            implementation, the supervision team should be supported by
            a well informed, proactive management structure, including a
            Country Operations Manager with front-line responsibility
            for service quality. 4. Use regularly scheduled portfolio
            reviews for increased quality control of Bank supervision
            activities. 5. Make available an extended team of project
            implementation specialists (procurement, financial
            management, ICT development, etc.) to support the task
            manager in resolving supervision problems. 6. Establish an
            effective implementation unit with adequate numbers of
            qualified staff experienced in supervising civil works,
            equipment procurement, staff training, financial management,
            and monitoring and evaluation for timely planning,
            implementation, and monitoring and evaluation of project
            activities. 7. Maintain the project manager for the duration
            of the project to ensure management continuity and involve
            him in project design, staff appointments, and initial
            training of project staff. 8. Positive and consistent
            support for the implementation unit from top-level education
            ministry officials is essential. 9. The training in logical
            framework strategies enabled the Educational Service Areas,
            project institution coordinators, and teachers to
            meaningfully participate in project implementation. Other
            lessons concerned establishing and operating an effective
            monitoring and evaluation for accurate progress reporting on
            quantitative and qualitative achievements at dispersed
            sites; adapting apt criteria for selecting candidates for
            overseas fellowships and short-term training, and providing
            translations at training courses in science research and use
            of advanced equipment; ensuring that the local provider does
            not infringe on international copyright laws; involving
            local university personnel to train staff in integrating ICT
            with the curriculum and instructional materials preparation;
            avoiding delays in procurement and disbursement by reducing
            differences between the Bank's and the
            Government's regulations; using vertical integration
            between institutions (e.g. universities, secondary schools)
            within a single subsector for effective institutional
            reform; and the need to shift from teacher-centered to
            student-centered teaching/learning methodology to improve
            student learning and retention; and improve secondary
            teachers' ability/opportunity to use ICTs in their classrooms.

repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Secondary Education Quality
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Secondary
            Education Quality Improvement Project will be to assist in
            raising the quality of secondary education in science and
            mathematics through strengthening teacher education in these
            subjects. Specifically, the project aims to: 1) raise the
            qualifications of teaching staff in selected Rajabhat
            Institutes (RIs) (teacher colleges) and enhance their
            understanding of modern teacher education techniques; 2)
            reinforce quality improvement in the RIs through modernizing
            science laboratories and workshops with up-to-date
            equipment, expanding laboratory space and refurbishing
            workshops; 3) expand the capacity of the RIs to carry out
            in-service training of secondary teachers; and 4) enhance
            the RIs capacity to undertake research and provide technical
            services to the community. The project will comprise the
            following components: 1) civil works to construct new
            science laboratories and to refurbish workshops; 2)
            equipment to modernize laboratories and workshops; 3)
            equipment-related operations and maintenance expenditures;
            4) an institutional development program consisting of
            fellowships and practical training for teaching staff, and
            in-service training for secondary teachers; 5) a research
            and technical services program which will include research
            grants and consultants to assist in the design of research
            projects and for new course development; and 6) assistance
            for project management and for the establishment of a
            monitoring and evaluation system.
